paratext: The following beautiful poem is from the conclusion of O.W. Holmes' "Professor at the Breakfast Table"  in the October number of the Atlantic. It is not excelled, by our taste, by anything in the language
author: O.W. Holmes
title: Under the Violets

paratext: Dr. Holmes concluded to his table-talk in the Atlantic Monthly for October with this sweet little poem. The reader will agree with us that the last stanza but one, contains, if not a new thought, at least one admirably uttered
author: O.W. Holmes
title: A Thought Well Uttered

paratext: The following is, we believe, acknowledged to be one of the tenderest poems ever written. Its author, as many of our readers perhaps already know, is that truest, wittiest, brightest of all American poets, the genial and delightful Oliver Wendell Holmes. There is not a line in "Under the Violets"  that does not throb with the heart of a true poet.
author: O.W. Holmes
title: Under the Violets

author: O.W. Holmes
title: Under the Violets
notes: The whole rest of the page is busincess cards

paratext: The sudden death of Miss Kate Bayard, daughter of secretary Bayard, as she was just leaving her home to assist Miss Cleveland at a receoption, was sad in the extreme. To see one so young and for whom life was blooming so beautifully and bright, so suddenly struck down, makes the heart swell and the eyes grow dim. Her death recalls Dr. Holmes' beautiful poem, "Under the Violets:"
author: O.W. Holmes
title: The Death of Miss Bayard
notes: Poem is printed in honor of a woman who died
